importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The day before the planned reopening of Khartoum international airport, the drone attacks disrupted the long-anticipated recovery of Sudan’s critical transportation infrastructure.

The conflict between the Sudanese army and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) began in April 2023, leading to the closure of Khartoum airport and widespread destruction of civilian and military infrastructure.
The drone attacks on Khartoum airport on October 21, 2025, mark the third such incident in seven days, signaling ongoing instability and the persistence of RSF attacks despite military advances.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The seven-day period from October 15 to 21, 2025, saw a spate of drone attacks on Khartoum, indicating a sustained pattern of RSF targeting of key infrastructure and military sites.

keyTakeAways: Drone attacks on Khartoum international airport occurred just one day before its scheduled reopening after over two years of closure due to conflict.
The attacks used 'suicide drones' and reportedly involved more than eight blasts, with some drones shot down by Sudanese military forces.
The Rapid Support Forces (RSF) are accused of carrying out the attacks, with reports indicating they are targeting military and civilian infrastructure from afar.
Khartoum has seen a series of drone strikes in recent days, including attacks on army bases in northwest Khartoum, suggesting ongoing asymmetric warfare.
Despite the army's recapture of Khartoum, large parts of the city remain in ruins, and frequent blackouts continue due to RSF drone activity.
The broader war has led to over 800,000 people returning to Khartoum, but widespread destruction and instability persist.
The RSF's continued efforts to seize el-Fasher in Darfur risk triggering large-scale ethnic violence and further humanitarian crises, with the UN issuing strong warnings.
The wider Sudan war has killed tens of thousands, displaced nearly 12 million, and created the world’s largest displacement and hunger crises.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A series of drone attacks, including multiple explosions near Khartoum international airport just one day before its planned reopening, have disrupted Sudan’s fragile recovery. The attacks, reportedly carried out by the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), mark the third such incident in seven days and reflect ongoing asymmetric warfare targeting military and civilian infrastructure. Despite the Sudanese army’s recapture of Khartoum and the return of over 800,000 civilians, widespread destruction and blackouts persist. The attacks also signal heightened risks in Darfur, where RSF forces are attempting to seize el-Fasher, prompting UN warnings of possible ethnic violence. The broader war has caused tens of thousands of deaths, displaced nearly 12 million, and created the world’s largest displacement and hunger crises.
title: Drone attack in Sudan threatens Khartoum airport’s reopening: Reports
